0618680004|2.0|Let me say this first:  I've read a good deal of Dawkins' work - Selfish Gene, Blind Watchmaker, River Out of Eden, Extended Phenotype, etc.  And, as a long-time former Atheist, now a Christian of sorts, I generally understand and can sympathize with Dawkins' worldview, even though I disagree.  This, however, is a sad book, where-in Dawkins' has finally ditched attempting to speak on the areas of his rather limited expertise (Biology, primarily), and is taking on religion, Christianity in particular, head-on, and in the process blunders repeatedly.  Like many similar books released as of late, it's only solid critiques crumble when faced with even the most moderately nuanced, and informed faith (folks steeped in the history of N.T. Wright, Marcus Borg, the scientific and theological insights of Alister McGrath, John Polkinghorne and/or the philosophy of Alvin Plantinga have nothing to fear here). <br /> <br />I just seems that Dawkins, a self-proclaimed rationalist, never fallows his rationality far enough to see the flaws in his own worldview, let alone be honest about them. For one, philosophical 'modernism' is long dead. The problem is this: if there is no God, and all you have is a modernist naturalistic understanding of 'truth', you can only use circular reasoning to justify your findings (and does he ever do so!), while the whole time arguing against the use of circular reasoning within other worldviews, such as Christianity - which is pure hypocracy. <br /> <br />I agree wholeheartedly with Philosopher of Science, Karl Popper, when he says, \\"I reject the naturalistic view: It is uncritical. Its upholders fail to notice that whenever they believe to have discovered a fact, they have only proposed a convention. Hence the convention is liable to turn into a dogma. This criticism of the naturalistic view applies not only to its criterion of meaning, but also to its idea of science, and consequently to its idea of scientific method.\\" Though Dawkins, a  self-proclaimed 'skeptic', adheres to naturalism, the problem with his skepticism is that he does not turn it to the foundations of his own worldview, which crumbles under its own weight of being unprovable on it's own terms. <br /> <br />Essentially, Dawkins' naturalism is like saying \\"I believe only in a, b, & c as truth, and will accept as fact only things that line up with a, b, & c\\", and then being suprised, and overjoyed, when discovering that you so-called 'facts' - SURPRISE - support a, b, & c! The reasoning is circular - which isn't , in itself bad (it's often necessary, within a post-modern epistemology), yet the whole enterprise of naturalism rejects circular reasoning, leaving naturalism internally inconsistent, and thus untenable. Isn't that at the heart of what we know as 'logic' - internal consistency? <br /> <br />Secondly, if naturalistic Darwinian evolution is assumed to be the 'guiding force' behind all that is, including our minds, chances are so slim as to be impossible - with a mind as such forces as chance & time would produce - that any 'facts' as they actually correspond to reality-as-it-is, let alone metaphysical, philosophical, and 'ultimate' answers, would be trustworthy. <br /> <br />Regarding this very issue, Charles Darwin himself wrote: <br />\\"With me, the horrid doubt always arises whether the convictions of man's mind, which has been developed from the mind of the lower animals, are of any value or at all trustworthy. Would anyone trust in the convictions of a monkey's mind...?\\" <br />(Charles Darwin, Letter to William Graham, Down, July 3rd, 1881.) <br /> <br />Alvin Plantinga, one of the world's leading philosophers and an expert on epistemology (the study of how we know what we know) and the philosophy of science, argues that there are no good reasons to suppose that natural selection (naturalistic Darwinian Evolution) is truth-conducive, that is, generally trustworthy or successful in producing 'minds' with the ability to reliably perceiveand understand the external world let alone to mentally construct even semi-accurate worldviews. He quotes contemporary philosopher of mind and philosophical naturalist Patricia Churchland to buttress this cl.. \\"She insists that the most important thing about the human brain is that it has evolved; this means, she says, that its principal function is to enable the organism to move appropriately: Boiled down to essentials, a nervous system enables the organism to succeed in the four F's: feeding, fleeing, fighting and 'reproducing'. The principle chore of nervous systems is to get the body parts where they should be in order that the organism may survive...Improvements in sensorimotor control confer an evolutionary advantage: a fancier style of representing is advantageous so long as it is geared to the organism's way of life and enhances the organism's chances of survival. Truth, whatever that is, definitely takes the hindmost.\\" (Alvin Plantinga, from \\"Naturalism Defeated\\") <br /> <br />Plantinga is basically pointing out that if philosophical naturalism denies the possibility that reality is guided or directed somehow (say, toward the creation of humans with reliable cognitive faculties) and if evolution selects only for survival value, it is highly unlikely that naturalistic evolution (unguided chance & time) would yield an evolved mind that accurately perceive reality, and therefore CAN know 'facts', apart from those most basic to survival - again, the four 'F's. If an individual is a pure Darwinian, they have no truly rational REASON to believe that they have reliable 'cognitive faculties', and therefore any theorizing from that point always stands upon a 'leap of faith' that their mind is properly engaging the world around them - with no real available evidence, apart from the fact that 'it seems to work for me' to ground that belief. As a result, \\"asserting that naturalistic evolution is true is also asserting that one has a low probability of being right inany of his assertions.\\" (Wikipedia) Quoting from another commenting on this same topic, \\"Ascribing truth to naturalism and evolution becomes self-referentially incoherent.\\" <br /> <br />That is why I do not trust naturalistic science's approach to what is 'fact' - it's incoherent, & self-contradictory - simply a 'leap of faith' within a system of thought/belief that discourages said 'leaps of faith' and is therefore internally inconsistent and proves itself not only untrue, but with no possiblity of being true. <br /> <br />Don't get me wrong, Science as historically practiced, is a field of study not necessariy grounded in naturalism/materialism - it can be very well argued that the scientific method not only grew out of a judea-christian-islamic (western religious) worldview, but that it wouldn't have developed at all without it, and it is ultimately within this context that it's findings make the most sense. In recent interviews all hands-on experimental scientists interviews said that the theory of darwinism, and naturalistic evolution, has absolutely no effect - positively or negatively - on their work, and without it they'd still do the exact same work that they've been at all along. Trust me, I absolutely LOVE the Sciences (having worked at a Scientific research library for several years), but the modern emphasis in some circles (mostly Biological Sciences) on Naturalism/Materialism I think we can ALL do without. <br /> <br />Anyway, combine this with McGrath's critique of Dawkins' meme theory - the fact that it, if applied consistently, actually explains to much as to explain away his theory itself.  Consider, how would we be able to know, if 'memes' were eventually proven to exist (any theory as to how this could be undertaken?), that his conceptualization of a meme were not a meme itself?   <br /> <br />So, in sum - good try Richard...you're an excellent writer (which is why you received 2 stars), but I agree with most of the literary community (the professional reviews of this book have been mediocre at best) - it appears - when I say: it seems best that you return to the biological sciences where you actually have a clue as to what you're talking about.

Pistone as possibly could be portrayed. Pistone was undercover (1976-1981) real gangsters in NYC were performing these horrible acts. All I can say is watching \\"Donnie Brasco\\" made me see the guts undercover officer Joseph D. Pistone had. It really took a special person to do what Joe did. For all his troubles, all Pistone got was a $500.00 check, a medal and a several year stay in the Witness Protection Program. Joe D. Pistone lives in annomity today as there is still a price on his head. \\"Donnie Brasco\\" is highly recommended viewing as it is portrayed realistically and authentically. Director Mike Newell definintly left the hollywood gangster out of this film........

015626224X|5.0|If you pick this little book up--while seated in your most comfortable chair, with a ready beverage nearby, and an empty bladder--odds are you'll finish it before you put it down again. Orwell is my kind of writer: he means what he says. This book imparts information, clearly and precisely; it is not a stylistic work, where the word trumps the meaning, and every syllabic filigree is employed. Here, the narrative is paramount (but the writing is still elegant and well-constructed). It is vastly entertaining, with Orwell's implacable candor, self-honesty, and knack for detail on full display.

B000MX7V5M|5.0|Alfred Hitchcock made two kinds of movies: bone-chilling thrillers that looked into the dark side of human nature, and witty adventure stories.<br /><br />\\"To Catch A Thief\\" is a sterling example of the latter kind of movie -- a chic, sleek, golden-tinted caper, full of witty dialogue and solid acting from legendary actors. Despite the taut action scenes, Hitchcock makes it feel almost like a cinematic vacation.<br /><br />Paul Robie (Cary Grant) was \\"The Cat,\\" the most notorious jewel thief in Europe, before he retired. But now impossible heists -- made in Robie's style -- are popping up all over Cannes, and he's the immediate suspect. Narrowly escaping the police, he enlists a friend to help him clear his name by capturing this new Cat.<br /><br />To do that, he masquerades as an American tourist, and gets to know pretty oil heiress Frances Stevens (Grace Kelly) and her mother. But when the Stevens jewels are stolen, Frances brings the cops down on Robie -- and now he is more desperate than ever to find the Cat, because he suspects it's an old friend...<br /><br />Hitchcock was in fine form with \\"To Catch a Thief,\\" especially since he had two great actors in the mix. Granted this isn't one of his more insightful or suspenseful movies, but it captures a sense of sly wit and fun instead.<br /><br />If \\"To Catch A Thief\\" has a problem, it's that astute viewers will be able to guess who the Cat is after about a half hour, maximum. But fortunately viewers can be distracted by Hitchcock's knack for razor-sharp dialogue (\\"What do you say?\\" \\"My only comment would be highly censorable\\") and double entendres (during an intimate lunch, Francie asks, \\"You want a leg or a breast?\\").<br /><br />It's also gorgeous to behold -- he entire movie is bathed in the golden Riviera sun, with lots of swimming, fast car chases, elaborate costume balls, and ornate hotels. But Hitchcock winds it up with a genuinely tense rooftop chase, complete with wrestling and gunshots.<br /><br />Grant is a bit grizzled (and VERY overtanned) here, but still dapper and charming enough for Robie, a thief with principles and a taste for the good life. Kelly is also quite good as an heiress who is less prim than she appears; John Williams and Jessie Royce Landis have fun supporting roles as a \\"veddy veddy English\\" insurance man and a shrewd rich woman.<br /><br />\\"To Catch A Thief\\" is a warm, sumptuous piece of classic film, with great dialogue and even better acting. I know that sounds pretty darned cliche but I must admit, it's true.  First of all - she's near 50 and is in incredible shape and how does one dance like that for a complete 2 hours?  The editing, performance, singing, etc... is all top notch.  The audio disc sound quality is perfect. <br /> <br />I think what I liked most about this show is that it wasn't pretentious (as I might have expected).  She gets out there (with complete drama - but little pretense) and gives you a show.  It's basically non-stop too. <br />Even the few classic songs presented here are completely reinterpretted and sound very fresh. <br /> <br />One thing I noticed was the Sorry remix video (one of my favorite parts of the show).  I clearly remember the video ending with Bush blinking his eyes repeatedly as Madonna said 'Don't Speak...'  In this version, he doesn't end the segment.  It could be in the editting though.  This piece was very powerful and disturbing live. <br /> <br />Granted, the live experience was something to witness (more than once) but this comes pretty close.

0521618789|5.0|The Tempest is rightly regarded as being one of the Bard's greatest works, containing some of his deepest thoughts on the nature of power and the relationship between rational man as controller of nature, and the animal man always to be at the mercy of the passions both of himself, others, and the world around him. In fact, this play could be thought of as representing Shakespeare's final and definitive statement on topics that he had explored throughout his cannon. But profound as the philosophy is, and despite the beauty of the poetry and the many magical elements contained within the play, the fact is that as far as the average attention lacking teenager is concerned, not a lot happens. This is why this Cambridge schools edition scores over most others. It is almost entirely activity focused, the expressed aim being to 'bring the play to life'. With at least one suggested activity beside each page of Shakespeare's text (as well as a decent amount of background notes and interpretation), every teacher armed with this book should be able to enthuse his charges with the very real relevance of this play to the world which we have bequeathed them.

B000FP2OPY|5.0|I'm not usually one for scary things of any kind - the movie IT scarred me for life, I think. So, when a friend recommended it, I was pretty doubtful that it would be my cup of tea. Of course, as the title states - each episode has supernatural elements in it (and sometimes quite scary ones too!) but that's not why I enjoyed this show so much! It's the characters of Sam and Dean that really make the show, and the actors that make the characters. I am and always will be a sucker for character development, and this show certainly weaves enough of that in between the supernatural monsters, spirits and demons to make me one contented viewer.  <br />John Winchester is more drill seargent than father, at least a lot of the time.  <br />Dean, the oldest son, has totally embraced the hunting lifestyle he was raised in. He unquestionably follows and respects his father (a continual sticking point between the two brothers), but also yearns for his family to be together and safe. Overtly protective, head strong and cocky - really, really, cocky; he hides his emotions in bad jokes, pranks and his ego. <br />Sam, on the other hand, has rejected the way that they were raised. He has issues with his father that have been unresolved since leaving to go to college, but loves the guy, so he joins Dean to find him. You can tell that Dean was more of the father-figure to him than John, and a lot of my favourite parts of the show are the dialogues that Sam and Dean share. Ah, brotherly love.  <br />Basically the story of the show: John Winchester's wife (Mary) is killed by a demon, prompting him to spend the rest of his life hunting down the thing that killed her, and any other supernatural things that he happens to come across on the way. His two young sons, Dean and Sam are pulled along with him, learning how to become skilled hunters as well. The show picks up after Sam (the younger brother) decides that hunting isn't for him and leaves his father and Dean for a normal life. He has been at Stanford for two years, until Dean comes to find him with the news that their father (who maybe had finally caught wind of the demon) has disappeared. Dean asks for Sam's help to find him, and the two hit the road... <br />Anyway, the characters and scripts are what makes this such a good show. It's good to watch something that has a story and character development in each episode, as well as a long running plot within the series, as I just don't have the patience to watch more ambigous shows like Lost. Highly recommended! Can't wait for the next series.   <br />

If you've already been double dipped by the Ghostbusters on DVD, picking this up is entirely up to you. B000A78Z82|4.0|I am astounded by people who say that \\"Cripple Crow\\" sounds 'too slick' for them. This mulligan's stew of music is so unslick that I often get distracted by the disparity. Twenty-two songs with six in Spanish and lo-fi recording that sounds like it was recorded in the woods somewhere...slick is not the word. Mystical, intimate and enthralling would be my adjectives of choice, though. Devendra Banhart has crafted a delightfully trippy excursion into his strange little world of freak-folk, a rich world inter-woven with imagistic lyrics and a decidedly anti-war bent.<br /><br />You'll hear echoes of everything from Bob Dylan, Solo Beatles Lennon, Harrison and McCartney and even a touch or two of Frank Zappa. Banhart is really fearless, musically. There isn't a genre inside his worldview that doesn't deserve trying out at least once, and if you miss listening to music that probably sounds better under a black light and something ingested (ok, I am over 40 and I admit it), \\"Cripple Crow\\" will suck you right into ecstasy. It's a total package, from the sitars and flutes inhabiting the songs to the homage to the 60's cover art. It's enough to give you faith in the underground music scene.<br /><br />My sole problem with this CD is that I feel it could benefit from some pruning. There's just too many ingredients in the stewpot to make a coherent disc, and the constant use of \\"child\\" or \\"womb\\" as a lyrical fall-back gets tedious over the duration of the disc. (As does Banhart's singing, like when he tires to go for soulfulness or when he screeches the final note of \\"Some People Ride The Wave.\\") There are songs that are downright goofy (\\"Long Haired Child\\" and \\"Chinese Children\\") and simple songs of great beauty (\\"I Heard Somebody Say\\" and \\"Inaneil\\"). It is easy to get hypnotized by the atmosphere of \\"Cripple Crow,\\" and Banhart is an eccentric with talent to burn. But for my money, any CD in 2005 willing to say \\"I heard somebody say that the war ended today...It's simple, we don't want to kill\\" is all right in my book.we don't want to kill\\" is all right in my book.

Never in this movie did I become bored. But as for you war-movie fans who only want blood and violence, this one will probably disappoint you, although its action scenes were done extremely well. The rest of the movie that hasn't been mentioned takes place before James Bradley wrote the book on which the movie was based. B000021XS0|5.0|Simply put, I love this album.  I am a sucker for a good concept album anyway and for me this is the disc where Dream Theater really put it all together to create the best work of their career so far.  The album is actually a continuation of the story first told in the track \\"Metropolis\\" from the \\"Images And Words\\" album 7 years earlier.  The story is fleshed out into a murder mystery that is told (and subsequently solved) through the main characters hypnotic regression of a former life.  The tale even has a M. Night Shamlyan like twist at the end.  It is one of the best thought out musical conceptual pieces I have ever heard.  It runs like a Broadway play only with Dream Theater's incredibly diverse and intense prog metal maniacal music, lyrics and vocals, it does not sound like anything you have ever heard in the theater.  It is really difficult for me to pick out highlights on this disc as I literally love every track.  The music all runs together and shines throughout.  You want technically brilliant instrumental interplay?  \\"The Dance Of Eternity\\" will blow you away.  You want outstanding use of vocal dynamics?  \\"\\"The Spirit Carries On\\" is one of James Labrie's all time shining moments.  You want great lyrics?  Pretty much the whole album listens like a good book.  It's all here, as Dream Theater put it all together.   One thing that must be noted is the addition of former Dixie Dreg member Jordan Rudess on keyboards.  Dream Theater had previously been the home of two very talented keyboard players in Kevin Moore, and Derek Sherinian.  It is hard to believe, but Rudess is even better then those two guys or at least his style appears to be the perfect fit with the band.  As I have already mentioned I think this is Dream Theater's strongest album to date (Feb 2007 as I write this), and is honestly one of my favorite progressive rock albums of all time.  If you like your prog with storyline, and plenty of bombast or if you have ever wanted to explore just what Dream Theater do, pick this album up.

This is what I like; she combines jazz, country, folk, soul, et al. This is also a wonderfully recorded album by Blue Note - imaging, soundstage, and presence to boot. Blue Note took their time in making this one - thanks. Hey, if this isn't your bag, move on.

B000JK8OYU|5.0|When I first heard about the \\"LOVE\\" CD, I did not know that the songs were actually remixes and overlayed on top of each other. After spending 17 years of my life doing remixes and editing songs, I was NOT ready to hear this done to the \\"sacred\\" work of the Beatles. And I found out (from reading other reviews of the CD) that I was not the only person that felt this way. To a lot of fans, doing this to Beatle songs was the same as painting a moustache on the Mona Lisa would be to art lovers.    After listening to the \\"LOVE\\" CD, all I can say is, \\"Hand me the paint brush and tell Mona I'm coming\\". The job done by George Martin and his son is a work to be appreciated, even if you are a die-hard Beatle fan.    In order to pull this project off and make it \\"work\\", you would need to have an encyclopedic knowledge of the Beatles recordings, from the ground up, which Sir George certainly does. You also need the studio chops to do the work. Again, no problem there. But most importantly, you would need to understand that the Beatles were innovators and were willing to experiment with not only sound but also with recording techniques, new instruments, different arrangements, playing tracks backwards, multiple track recording etc. All of these things have been taken into account in the creation of the \\"LOVE\\" CD. It comes very, very close to being, in effect, a new Beatles CD.    The flow of the CD is very well done. Even if the material was pulled together for a \\"soundtrack\\" to a Las Vegas production, it is well thought out for a listening experience. The choice of material is a good representation of the Beatles entire recording career, from Parlophone to Apple. And the production values are stellar, considering that these recordings are 40+ years old. I have never heard John, Paul, George & Ringo sound THIS GOOD!    I would recommend this CD to anyone who:    1. Appreciates the Beatles  2. Appreciates creativity and the willingness to experiment, and  3. Anyone who has neverheard the Beatles (if such people truly exist)    George Martin gets a big ol' thumbs up from me for this effort. Now..... Howzabout \\"LOVE 2\\"????

Dover is to be commended for making texts such as these affordable for readers on a budget.  However, students and teachers alike should note that the Dover edition does not supply line numbers.  Students who are considering this text for a class and may have to write about it will not be able to cite specific line numbers as is convention (Act.scene.lines; e.g., 3.1.34-47).  Professors and teachers should also be aware of this limitation and weigh it against the affordability of this text.

044100590X|5.0|\\"Dune\\" is an unusual science fiction novel in that it takes place thousands of years in humanity's future, but there are no computers. Instead, the universe of  \\"Dune\\" is shaped by organic concepts: mysticism and ecology, intelligent machines having been banned. Great Houses govern their planets as fiefdoms. Duke Leto of the House Atreides is sent to rule the desert planet Arrakis, the source of the spice melange, upon which all economic, social, and political structure depends. The drug facilitates preternatural computational and intuitive abilities in its users. The Harkonnen Baron, a ruthlessly ambitious leader of a rival House, plots the murder of Duke Leto, his concubine Jessica, and their teenaged son Paul in order to reclaim Arrakis. But he has underestimated young Paul, who may be the prophesied savior, a male who possesses the greatest powers of the female mystic sect Bene Gesserit. And he has underestimated the fierce Fremen desert people, whose ambitions and accomplishments defy their primitive reputation.<br /><br />\\"Dune\\" excels in evoking a culture with values very different than our own but connected to us by bits and pieces of Islamic and Christian doctrine that readers will recognize. The unusual social structure and value systems of these future humans appeal to the imagination. And the ability to read what the characters are thinking  -always in italics- involves the reader in their lives and minds. The only fault I find with the novel is that it is long, spending more time than necessary on Paul and Jessica's flight through the desert and struggles amongst the Fremen. But the excessive time spent with some characters does immunize \\"Dune\\" from the poor character development that is common to science fiction. The politics of the story are utterly arcane. But author Frank Herbert has grasped the idea that cultures are defined by their limitations, and he makes excellent use of Arrakis' limited water supply as the defining characteristic of Fremen society. \\"Dune\\"'s vivid cultures and page-turning adventure make it one of the great works of science fiction.society. \\"Dune\\"'s vivid cultures and page-turning adventure make it one of the great works of science fiction.

B000LPQ6DE|4.0|Unlike the 1995 BBC version of Pride and Prejudice with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, you will not doubt that you are watching a film and not reading the book.  The previously mentioned movie was taken almost exactly from the book.  However, while this version isn't perfection, it comes very close. <br /> <br />Perhaps the main problem with most productions of Jane Eyre is the portrayal of Rochester.  In many productions an actor may be able to convey Rochester's fiery temperament, but not his philosophical playfulness or tenderness.  Other actors may have down the philosophical qualities, but they are usually overdone to the point that Rochester seems completely out of touch with everyone.  Still other Rochesters get all the passion, but forget that there is more than sex on this man's mind.  However, Toby Stephens has portrayed Rochester to perfection.  When you see this production, you will immediately see the perfect balance of mischievousness, wrath, passion, playfulness, thoughtfulness, and melancholy that makes Rochester so difficult to portray. <br /> <br />However, there are two matters which prevent me from giving this production an outright 5 star perfection. <br /> <br />Firstly, there is very little time spent on Jane's childhood, and Miss Temple is completely absent.  But, surprisingly, I didn't feel too cheated.  The director and writer came up with a very agreeable way of incorporating much into a very short sequence of events.  Any book enthusiast will be pleased. The alterations were not drastic. <br /> <br />Secondly, I do have probably the most problem with Jane's departure from Thornfield.  This is the only time that Rochester does not live up to his full potential.  Instead of being nearly violent, as in the book, there is instead some quiet coercion in Jane's bedroom.(Don't worry. It's just the location for the chat.  They are only talking in this scene). Instead of being threatening, he is pleading.  However, I don't think this is any faulton Stephens's part. I believe this to be the work of both director and writer, as this scene is also segmented through the entire second half of the film. <br /> <br />Altogether, with the combination of acting talent, good writing, and excellent directing, I think this a nearly perfect production.  The scenes have almost been taken word for word, and where they haven't been, the spirit of the book has been maintained to perfection.  <br /> <br />As I said, there is really only one scene I can really quibble about, and really it was't enough of a disappointment to keep me from buying a copy immediately after viewing it.  I am extremely pleased.  Don't waste your time on other productions.  This is the one.

B000001GRE|4.0|Mahler's 7th is a tough and perhaps uncrackable nut. Interpreters like Bernstein perform the equivalent of plastic surgery, tart it up emotionally, and makes excuses that Mahler really intended the final movement as a \\"parody\\" of \\"kapellmeistermusik\\". Boulez lays the patient etherised on a table and does an autopsy. Diagnosis: this IS kapellmeistermusik!<br /><br />For classical music collectors, having several versions of a work is essential to understanding the piece. Rarely is there a \\"definitive\\", only-recording-needed version. If you think you \\"know\\" Mahler's 7th but haven't heard this version, you're kidding yourself. Sonically outstanding, too.
B00006F7S4|5.0|As an old Beck fan, I bought this album on its release date without knowing one thing about it. The result was listening to it every day for weeks and weeks.     I was amazed by every melody of this album and not so much because it's truly original (that might be a subjective statement), but because it added so much depth to Beck's persona as a musician and songwriter. He suddenly became 3D and human for the first time since One Foot in the Grave. The lyrics are far more straightforward and heart-felt than any previous release, which I think is a core reason for some people's disappointment - you might love the word play from Odelay and Mellow Gold, but that doesn't mean you can't appreciate something serious and trust me, this album is very serious. In my experience, it's easily the most depressingly lovely album since the Cure's Disintegration. I'm not comparing the sounds by any means, just the sadness they convey.    Hard to pinpoint standout tracks, because it's really best listened to as a whole and there are no weaknesses. I guess if I had to choose my personal favorites, they would be \\"The Golden Age\\", \\"Guess I'm Doin' Fine\\", \\"Lonesome Tears\\", \\"Lost Cause\\" and \\"Sunday Sun\\". Honorable mentions to \\"Little One\\" and \\"Round the Bend\\".     While I don't doubt that Beck is always questing to push his own limits and explore uncharted waters, this album clearly stems from the notion of self-therapy & healing vs. producing something that will sell. I have an artist friend who was actually angry that Beck \\"let down his fans\\" with Sea Change; if you don't like it, that's fine....but don't pin your preferences on one's artistic integrity. Unbeknownst to most of the pre-canned, garbage bands out there, it's not a musician/artist's job to please others, it's their job to make music/art that they want to make. People liking it is just a bonus.  But shhhh, don't tell the record companies...you might rock the boat.    Cheers to Beck for marching to his own beat, again.
B000LPQ6DE|3.0|After her stunning and brilliant Direction of BLEAK HOUSE last season, Susanna White creates a visually stark and beautiful to look at version of JANE EYRE.  But this is not Bronte's Eyre... in fact it is one of the most mentally wrong versions I've seen. You'd need to go back to the 1930s early talkie version with Virginia Bruce to find a Rochester as simply wrong in every way as Toby Stephens is here.<br /><br />A lot of this problem is the script, which translates Rochester and Jane into the mental set of a two-timing husband trying to pick up a shy co-ed in a singles bar.  Just plain ikky.<br /><br />JANE EYRE is difficult to translate well onto screen because her major relationship in the book is NOT with Rochester, it is with God, it permeates her upbringing, her time at Rochester's house, her struggles, her time at the house of the Pastor & his sisters, her refusal of missionary work, and the end.  Bronte was a brilliant, incisive religious thinker who used this story to pinpoint that a relationship with God can be a reason to relieve yourself from mission work for the wrong reasons, just as it can be a drive to deny your heart's wish because that, too is wrong.<br /><br />Even if you take out bits of the story, you can retain this mindset.  When you remove this mindset, which THIS gloriously costumed, photographed, and settinged production does, you deteriorate the characters into \\"Jane and Rochester Rock the Canopy Bed\\".  That should have been the title of this one... so very WB network (or now CW network).<br /><br />This is my favorite book, & I've seen - several times - almost every version made of this story, and have a collection of it.  Not only do I not want this version, I could not make myself watch all of it - I kept turning it off and coming back.  I was disgusted by watching Jane and Rochester snog on the sofa and put down Miss Fairfax.<br /><br />So wrongheaded, Bronte must be spinning in her grave like a silkworm junkie that needs a fix.  JANE EYRE is the story of two physically unattrative people, drawn together by understanding of their souls.  There has not been ONE version yet that has cast BOTH roles this way, and I defy a major studio to do it.  (The closest was probably Zefferelli's version.)<br /><br />Ruth Wilson, tall, elegantly slender, not beautiful, but in every way attractive by today's standards, and Toby Stephens, the greasy-haired six-pack ab workout hottie, are both about as wrong as you can get physically.  The 40s version with Welles and Fontaine took tremendous liberties with the book and they're both attractive, but they both eminate the souls found in the book in a production that just reeks of the spirit.<br /><br />But the real corker here is the way Rochester is written and played. He might as well be mubbling his way through a Sam Sheppard play!  If you are seriously REVIEWING this DVD you HAVE to distinquish between lusting after Toby like pre-pubescent teens & Rochester the timeless character. Best Rochester ever is Ciarin Hinds in the version with Samatha Morton.  HE is still too tall, too handsome, but WOW.  100% got the book down.  (Morton, on the other hand, a fine actress, looks the part but sneers and smirks like a demi-monde courtesan... wierd, wierd choices.)<br /><br />So this missed effort - I gave it a 3 - Why so high?  The production values are that high.  Really, that detail correct, that beautiful to behold.  Which makes the sum of the parts that much more insufferably frustrating. B000LPQ6DE|5.0|With the 1995 adaptation of Pride and Prejudice the BBC set a new standard for literaty adaptations. Fortunately it's one that they've been able live up to, Most recently in this recent adaptation of Jane Eyre.     Overall it's a highly recommended adaptation. Is it 100% true to the novel? No but  since that's not really what I look for in an adaptation. The question is, does it stand on it's own merits? Yes.     Ruth Wilson is really likable as Jane Eyre and I think that she has a exciting career ahead of her. I look foreward to seeing what she does next. Her Jane is less plain than others are and probably less so than Bronte wrote the character. From the begining there's a sparkle in her eye. She's less repressed, and all the brains and spirit that are initially well hidden in Bront's Jane are bubbling just beneath the surface of Wilson's.  Likewise, Toby Stephen's Rochester is younger and better looking than I usually imagine the character. But his harshness is tempered with a wonderfully sardonic wit. He's a man who has had a difficult life but he looks back on it with a rueful sense of humor.     Once or twice it seemed as if the filmmakers were trying to make the film \\"sexy\\" in unnecessary ways. At one point Jane saves Mr. Rochester's life. When he  thanks her, he asks to shake her hand. Instead he takes both her hands in both of his and moves in very close. I was truely expecting a make-out scene. It just seemed more Supermarket Checkout Line Romance, then Victorian Gothic Romance. It's a romantic story to begin with- no need to turn it into a bodice ripper. These scenes aren't needed but the chemistry between the leads makes them work.     A few reviewers have critized the two leads for being too attractive, betraying the idea of the book. However that assumes that the book is about ugly people falling in love. It's not. It's about a woman growing and establishing herself in life without the benefit of money, social connections or an exceptional physical appearance. Jane Eyre had endured as a work of literature due to the romantic and at times suspensful nature of the plot, the strong sense of atmosphere, a sense of with and intelligence and above all an immensely likable heroine (despite or perhaps because of her lack of glamour) While it leaves out a few potions of the novel, this film preserves the important qualities.

1592401791|5.0|For fans of Beatles lore, Here There and Everywhere by Geoff Emerick is a thoroughly enjoyable read. I thought a book written by a former EMI sound engineer who worked on many Beatles albums would be a challenge. After all, how well could someone write who has worked at a mixing board most of his life? But I was pleasantly surprised. Primarily because Emerick had a very competent writer help him in his literary endeavor. Emerick was fortunate enough to be at the Beatles very first recording session and their last. His first day at work at the pimply age of 16 happened to coincide with the Fab Four's recording of-How Do You Do It-a song which they didn't write and refused to make their own. Emerick has the unique point-of-view that only a lowly-nobody can have. Considering his long friendship with Paul McCartney, his assessments of events and problems within the group seem candidly fair. Emerick was the main engineer for the albums: Revolver, Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, Magical Mystery Tour, part of the White Album, and Abby Road. Quite revealing, for me anyway, was how much the Beatles interest in new sounds were accomodated by Emerick and not producer George Martin. For the most part, Martin left Emerick to figure out how to fill Beatle requests for unorthodox and sometimes whacky sounds. I highly recommend this book!

Do us a favor...stop while you're reasonably ahead.

0875428940|3.0|This deck is often famed for it's attention to the minor arcana's art, its use of pagan symbology, and being a faithful follower to the Rider-Waite style. As a purely divination deck- it fulfills all expectations of performance. The stock of the cards is good, and their size perfect for use and laying out. <br /> <br />However, I find myself highly underwhelmed. The minor arcana art is indeed fantastic- and I can see why they talk about it so heavily after the utter boredom that was the major arcana. I am no stranger to nudity in Tarot and think little enough when it's done tastefully...there were points this deck was pushing the tasteful bar among the major arcana. Nor was the art particuarly impressive to me in the major, as noted. They brag that the minor arcana were not an afterthought- I can agree. This time it looks like the major arcana were. <br /> <br />To the claims of pagan symbolism I agree the deck mostly adheres to this- yet I find some of the symbol choices oddly placed: Such as a male angel-style figure on the Temperance card (a card largely noted as being 'feminine' to balance the oft-masculine Chariot) and the use of a Phoenix on a card that remains as Judgement...a symbol and a card that have very little in common. The less often seen Rebirth or Rejuvenation would have been a better fit to my mind, though I freely admit this is solely my opinion. <br /> <br />My gripe regarding the magician holding eternity (the Loop) rather than being crowned by it and leaving the wand among the other symbols is one not exclusive to this deck sadly. It's just being mentioned as I took the time to mention the other issues I had with other cards in this deck. <br /> <br />However, as many have said- the minor arcana are indeed fantastic. The deck is worth seeing if only to behold the works of art that are these 56 cards. It's just a tragedy the majority of the intial 22 are not so wonderous. My sole exception to that is the Fool. So it's not a bad buy- it's a realdivination deck- but don't buy into all the artistic and symbolic hype.

B000ICL3KG|3.0|Vice President Al Gore and director Davis Guggenheim have teamed up together to provide a compelling presentation.  Using charts and statistics with the simple, effective skills President Reagan used, Al Gore goes through diagnosing, sampling, then convincing us of the existence of global warming.  Having been no stranger to the topic for decades, he demonstrates stunning global pictures that document its effects upon the entire global landscape.  Beautiful cinematography and quiet evocative music garnish his presentation that is poignantly laced with autobiographical narratives of key moments of his life.  Also, he interrupts his lecture to tell some funny jokes to keep the electricity of the audience flowing.  The former Vice President takes his composite picture and evidence, and, then he asserts that it is a moral, not a political imperative that we reverse these trends with a myriad of CO2 reducing porposals.  He also, like a skillful debater, surfaces the rebuttals by the opposition and offers his own counterpoints.  (For instance, he honestly shows that C02 levels go in cycles over a long history even before scientists obtained the means to measure it, but one of his most eye-opening statistic is that C02 levels have never been 300 parts per million until now.  No cycle has ever looked as C02 saturated as long or as hugely as the time in which we now live.)    This documentary should be seen by everyone, especially the skeptics.  Most of the people who comment about the movie were already convinced of global warming, but that isn't to say there's no wisdom in firing up the troups.  Global warming is such a divisive issue, and the ramifications are so important that, even those who believe that global warming is a hoax or that it is real, but a natural cycle, need to know what they're debating.  It is always illuminating to know more about what you believe, but it's also important for the general public to get a hearing about a major issue.      There were a couple of minor weaknesses.  First of all, Vice President Al Gore is a politician.  Most commentators say this isn't a political DVD.  Not true.  To the liberals, I say, it is political.  To the conservatives, I say, who cares?  In the middle of the DVD, the movie shows the 2000 Presidential race debacle.  This happens a long time after the Vice President makes the point that the Bush Administration has abandoned its promises about the environment.  The context of film clips of the election is political.  Convincing the public of global warming is a political debate.  Al Gore does a great job, but I thought the brief lapse with the 2000 election detracted from his message briefly.  Secondly, and also minor, his charts show that global warming has brought about an increase of new species.  (Shouldn't we be frightened if the changes didn't?  Afterall, where would we be if that didn't happen with the climate changes that wiped out the dinosaurs?)  He then adds that trees have been devastated by growing species of beetles.  (Maybe new, sturdier trees will evolve.  Of course moral presumption in environmental matters isn't prudent, either.)    One of the best arguments he makes is about money.  He shows how little dissent there is among scientists, except those paid by corporations, like oil companies.  One of his best analogies is when he shows that there were ads after the surgeon general's claims about smoking, which read, \\"More doctors smoke Camels than any other brand.\\"  Such is the opposition now to global warming.      Is Al Gore cherry picking highlights or an environmental Henny Penny?  The results are too important not to be focused and find out for ourselves.  Everyone should see this movie.
B000HEWEEE|1.0|I'm surprised at the stellar reviews for this movie.  It has all the peppy pacing and snappy ambiance of a funeral dirge.  Both Sandra Bullock and Keanu Reeves must have done something to annoy the cameraman, because I have never seen them look so utterly unattractive. The dialogue is stilted and trite, and its delivery is usually in monotones.  The closest these two could ever come to generating electricity is by briskly rubbing their stockinged feet over a synthetic rug on a really cold dry day.  I was so hoping to like the movie, because I thought the premise was interesting.  By the end of the movie, I was so disappointed in the director, actors, scriptwriters, and the sappy music that I was compelled to write this review.  Don't buy - rent.  Even then you'll find it a frustrating waste of time.
B000002NIW|5.0|There was a time when I regarded The Deftones sophomore album as their weakest link, but after another listen I began to realize that it very well may be their strongest.  Mixing almost to perfection everything that made `Adrenaline' so pulse pounding and everything that made `White Pony' so revolutionary; `Around the Fur' is the perfect transitional piece to show where a brilliant band was headed, musically and emotionally.  Starting things off with the infectious `My Own Summer' and ending things with the strangely inviting `MX'; `Around the Fur' is close to perfection. <br /> <br />`My Own Summer' starts things off brilliantly.  It sports a great riff, fun to listen to and even more fun to play.  Chino's vocals are great and his screaming is just infectious (I actually have this song as my cell phone ring tone).  This was one of the first Deftones songs I ever heard.  It graced `The Matrix' soundtrack and proved to be the best reason to own the soundtrack in the first place.  Brilliant way to start an album.  Grabs you immediately and keeps you clenched in their claws. <br /> <br />`Lhabia' is another brutal track but the next surprise comes in the form of `Mascara' which is much slower, eerier and at times somewhat disturbing.  Some have noted this may be about an abusive relationship, and I can see that here.  It's beautiful in it's oddity for it's not a song you'd expect from this band, but it's a welcome addition to a masterpiece. <br /> <br />`Around the Fur', the title track to this album, is everything you'd want in a Deftones song.  It starts off with some great drum work and then fills out much the way of `My Own Summer', commanding and infectious, a song you can sing along with and get completely stuck in your head.  My old band used to play this song a lot because it's diverse yet not too complex.  It's not standard so it's interesting, yet it's not too complicated to where you get lost figuring it out.  Chino's lyrics are great here; different and thought provoking...the best thing about this band is Chino's genius. <br /> <br />`Rickets' is again, brutal.  `Be Quite and Drive' on the other hand is not so brutal.  Some have regarded it as the best song The Deftones have released but I strongly disagree.  `Passenger' was far better (still my all time favorite Deftones song).  I actually hated this song when I first heard it.  I wasn't impressed, but the more I listen to it the more it grows on me.  I actually really enjoy it now...but that took a while. <br /> <br />`Lotion' is straight Deftones, a track that could have passed for `Adrenaline'.  Chino sounds furious throughout this song, and when he chants \\"I feel sick\\" you just know they nailed this song, they got it right.  One of the things they do VERY right is `Dai the Flu' a song that stands alone as the best track on `Around the Fur'.  It's eerie to a degree and completely contagious, a song that's unlike any other they've done.  Chino's vocals are impressive, soft and delicate not to mention strong and determined.   <br /> <br />`Headup' has Chino trading lines with Max Cavalera from Soulfly.  It's brutal, intense and proof that the ONLY band that should even attempt the whole rap/rock thing is The Deftones.  They just get it right.  The closing track `MX' features almost a conversation type verse between Chino and a woman.  It's a very different kind of song, but it's very well done and makes you want to listen to it over and over.  A great way to close out an album.  So, in closing...this is a fantastic contribution to the brilliance that is The Deftones and will look and sound pretty good in any CD collection!
B000083E79|5.0|An amazing span of work. Cher truly knew how to reinvent herself over the decades and come out with a winning hit that would have next generations of fans listening to her songs. Way to go Cher! I like all of the songs on this cd.
B000002J6H|5.0|I write this in the winter, with just a bit of snow on the ground.  And when it gets like this outside, when the air is crisp and biting but the sun is shining, I can't help but hark back to one of my very favorite albums of all time, Stephen Stills's first solo effort.  Back in 1970, Steve Stills was beautiful.  And those sideburns!  I was in love.  And I played that album over and over again and I stared at the cover.  And I dreamed of sitting by him in the snow, with the giraffe, and listening to him play.  It wasn't until I got older and got the CD, and didn't have to flip the record over to hear the second side, that I truly appreciated the musicianship on this album.  I think this is one of the finest rock-blues albums ever recorded.  His pals who played on it with him were the stars of the time, and none of them had their names above the title.  And while I don't think that Stills ever surpassed his effort on this album, I do think that muscially, he was the star of CSN&Y.  I like Neil Young, but even listening to one of my favorites of his, After the Gold Rush, the differences in melody and musical skill are startling.  \\"Stephen Stills\\" resonates strongest for those of us for whom this had meaning over 35 years ago (gulp!), but the music is still powerful today.  It is a truly great album from a truly accomplished musician.

B000957O82|4.0|Displaying that he can handle the lead role in a romantic comedy just as easily as he can handle every other genre in the field, Will Smith shines in HITCH as Alex Hitchens, aka \\"The Date Doctor.\\"  Hitch helps average guys gain the attention and win the hearts of the women of their dreams.  He has a strict code that he follows and his identity has remained a secret.<br /><br />Hitch is hired by a tax accountant named Albert (Kevin James).  Albert is an overweight, average-Joe who happens to work at a firm that handles starlet Allegra Cole's (Amber Valleta) accounts.  Allegra Cole is a celebrity and has all the money, fame, power, and beauty that comes with her station.  Albert falls deeply in love with Ms. Cole and needs help getting her attention.  This is a romantic comedy, so even the most improbable scenarios become likely and soon Albert finds himself dating the famous Allegra Cole.<br /><br />Meanwhile, Hitch has some problems of his own.  He's fallen for a national gossip columnist, Sara (Eva Mendes) who is trying to figure out who the unknown man Allegra Cole has been seen with really is.  Hitch is a true genius at setting up scenarios for his clients, but all of the tricks he uses to help his clients have the opposite effect when he uses them with Sara.  For example, A romantic trip to Ellis Island turns Sara into a raging and crying fury of hatred and a night at a make-your-own seafood place has Hitch breaking out in a serious facial reaction.  As Hitch and Sara bond with each other, their relationship becomes increasingly rocky when a spurned client turns on Hitch and Sara learns what he really does for a living.<br /><br />The poster and DVD cover for HITCH say that \\"Will Smith is `Hitch'\\".  There's no better way to explain it because Smith is Hitch.  Every gesture, move, and spoken phrase seems perfect.  Hitch is a role that Smith was born to play.  But Smith doesn't shine alone in the film.  Eva Mendes is a beautiful woman, but she's also incredibly talented.  She holds her own against one of Hollywood's most powerful actors.  From various interviews she has given, Mendes seems like a down-to-Earth person.  That reality grounds Sara and radiates through her and makes her someone that the audience cares for.  Kevin James does an excellent job as the film's pivotal-plot character Albert and in many scenes upstages Smith.<br /><br />I tend to like most genres of movies as long as there is a good story involved.  However, romantic comedies are my least favorite film genre.  Many romantic comedies made are trite and have no originality to them.  HITCH really isn't like that.  The movie has a good story, great actors, and solid direction.  It's both funny and tender.  Unlike many movies in he genre, HITCH is a movie that a person can enjoy watching by themselves just as much as watching it with a loved one.<br /><br />Recommended for fans of romantic comedies, fans of Will Smith, fans of Eva Mendes, and fans of Kevin James.  For movie trivia fans, the fire station shown at the beginning of the movie as Hitch is helping a client is the same firehouse used in GHOSTBUSTERS.bly talented. 0385751060|5.0|This novel is soooooo wonderful! Sparse, but so layered with complexity (even though that sounds like an oxymoron), Boyne writes of the holocaust from the eyes of a young boy. Bruno doesn't understand why he and his family had to leave their warm, safe cozy home in Berlin to follow his father's job and settle at \\"Out-With\\". Bruno's new home is just yards from the fence that contains one of the most horrifying concentration camps on record. And even though Bruno doesn't understand what his father's job is (only that he is much praised by \\"The Fury\\"), he knows that \\"Out-With\\" is not a safe or happy place. And he wonders about all the people he sees over the fence who are wearing grey striped pajamas. Eventually his adventurous spirit overrides his parents' orders to stay away from the fence and he goes exploring. At the fence edge he meets a boy his exact age (a deftly written \\"mirror image\\" of Bruno). The boys develop a friendship and through this friendship, Boyne illustrates how easily the tables could be turned. It just as easily could be Bruno fenced in. The holocaust is hard for adult minds to grasp, and it is exponentially more so for a child's. In the stunning denoument, Boyne illustrates so clearly how difficult it is to distinguish one person from another once the labels have been removed.<br /><br />I would recommend this book to anyone!

Thanks, Robert.<br /><br />This book is the foundation for it all.  Yes, it is vague, because your way is different from mine. B00006SFLV|5.0|This remains the one truly great and overlooked television creation of the 1990s. The ensemble acting, storytelling skills, production values, and emotional substance are as compelling for me now as when I first saw this series in 1995. That persistence, after what must now be ten viewings of each episode, is unique for me, as for thousands of others.<br /><br />Unfortunately, it didn't get a chance to be thus adopted by millions of others, when this first aired, and that (along with ABC's well-documented corporate cowardice) is why it didn't continue for even a full 24-to-26-episode season.<br /><br />I won't repeat the descriptive (and accurate) points brought out well by many of the other customers. I'll note here one crucial aspect that is often under-mentioned: \\"MSCL\\" is not solely about the teenagers. It revolves around a group of friends of that age. Yet it puts the stories firmly in the settings of their families and their teachers, as well. One knows the context and hidden facets for all the characters' lives, even within only 900 minutes.<br /><br />This came from both serendipity and law. Claire Danes (Angela) and Devon Gummersall (Brian), portraying the two central threads of characterization, were 14 to 15 when this was made, and had strong legal restrictions on their work hours. That meant more scenes had to be written or rewritten to highlight and deepen their characters' friends. All of them were portrayed by actors with more liberal hours, but who were still all teenagers, rare both then and now.<br /><br />Most of all, it meant that the adults had to have substantial screen time. It shows most of all in the emotional dimensions opened up for, and by, Bess Armstrong (Patty Chase) and Tom Irwin (Graham Chase). That broadened scope is one of the strongest reasons why this series still resonates, especially for many in our 30s and 40s, when any number of sitcoms and formula dramas using pre-fab parental stereotypes have faded from cultural memory.<br /><br />The video quality of these discs is immaculate. The only added feature is the English subtitles. You get the writing and acting, with menus (which do show scenes in the background), those made to shine in a nearly flawless transfer, but nothing else.<br /><br />The sound defaults to the Dolby 5.1 Surround track, but many have found this a bit hollow, and that the Dolby 2.0 track works better to punch up the nearly constant dialogue. The track choice can be set once to cover the full viewing of any one disc. (Also, a few moments on Disc 3 have the 5.1 Surround sound out of sync.)<br /><br />If you purchase this set from a non-U.S. seller, you won't be out of luck, as the discs are, in fact, region-free, not \\"region 1,\\" as they are marked.<br /><br />... Edited (August 2008) to remove notes on re-releases, as Shout! Factory has since created a far superior set. ([[ASIN:B000TXZVGQ My So-Called Life - The Complete Series (w/ Book)]]) This set, though, does get the series' brilliance across fully, if you choose to buy it used.is immaculate. B00008MLSH|4.0|Anna Netrebko has rapidly become a first tier star in opera.  This album, her first at DGG, illustrates why some rate her so highly; it also illustrates some of the questions that some have raised about her.  All in all, though, a very nice CD.<br /><br />A few selections illustrate:<br /><br />Mozart, Idomeneo, \\"Quando avran fine omai.\\"  She displays a rich and clean voice.  There is a very attractive quality to her voice manifest in this work.<br /><br />Mozart, Don Giovanni, \\"Crudele? Ah no, mio bene!...Non mi dir.\\"  This is Donna Anna's poignant aria, given her circumstances.  Netrebko displays rich tones.  This is a well sung cut.  \\"Non mi dir\\" shows off some agility in her voice.<br /><br />Donizetti, Lucia di Lammermoor.  \\"Ancor non giunse!. . .Regnava nel silenzio. . .Quando rapito in estasi\\"  Something of a disappointment.  Coloratura is not her forte (and see her \\"Sempre Libera\\" CD for further confirmation).  She clearly shows off a rich and lush voice.  I think that she displays some characterization here that is compelling.  She hits high notes cleanly.  But her ornamentation is indifferent, and she appears unable to trill.  I know, some say that that is irrelevant. But compare Beverly Sills' version of this work, with almost too many trills extraordinarily well sung and her florid technique, and this version simply pales.<br /><br />Bellini, La Sonnambula.  \\"Care compagna. . .Come per me sereno.\\"  Again, Netrebko displays a rich voice.  She displays an agile voice and the ability to hit the high notes.  Her rendition of \\"come per sereno\\" is spirited.<br /><br />Gounod, Faust. \\"The Jewel Song.\\" Very smooth singing; animated singing.  But the technique does not measure up to Anna Moffo's version--let alone Joan Sutherland's.<br /><br />Puccini, La Boheme.  \\"Musetta's Waltz.\\"  Yikes!  What a version.  Brava Netrebko.  Her darker voice is very well suited to this.  The characterization of Musetta seems on the mark.  A wonderful cut.<br /><br />All in all, this shows the promise of Netrebko.  It also indicates where her strengths are and where she does not do so well (coloratura work).  However, this is a very nice introduction to her work and her art./>All in all, this shows the promise of Netrebko.  It also indicates where her strengths are and where she does not do so well (coloratura work).  However, this is a very nice introduction to her work and her art. <br />

B000KQGP2G|5.0|First of all, THIS IS PART II of the Perfect Element concept:<br /><br />1) Daniel states in an interview given at the morow website:<br /><br />\\"Conceptually it is the followup to 'The Perfect Element Part One' so to kind of end all of these discussions that have been flourishing on the internet in different forms -  the answer is positive - yes it is the second part of the perfect element, but we have had...like...we have kind of tried to hidden it as much as possible because we don't want people to buy 'Scarsick' because it is the second part of the perfect element...\\"<br /><br />2) The band's news section of their website states:<br /><br />\\"the many fans who spent weeks and weeks discussing the possibility of this album being The Perfect Element Part II were finally able to say \\"What did I tell you\\" when the official copies reached the stores, ending a long wait and putting an end to the obligatory interview question \\"When will TPE2 come?\\" (or rather just replacing it with \\"When will TPE3 come?\\"). \\"<br /><br />3) Notice that the inside of the CD case says 'the perfect element, part II - \\"he\\"' - the  first words in the insert read 'part II' and the end of the booklet reads \\"to be continued\\"!!!<br /><br />So now we can all wait for The Perfect Element III!<br /><br />NOW ONTO THE REVIEW OF THE ALBUM:<br /><br />Musically, TPEI seemed to follow a very cohesive (yet amazingly complex and diverse) sound throughout the album - highlighted mostly by epic sounding guitar and keyboard melodies. 'Scarsick' on the other hand is a completely different sounding album...<br /><br />\\"Scarsick\\" - the opening track, has the similar rap-technique that Daniel utilized on the opening track of TPEI 'Used'. The 'rapping' is nothing he hasn't done before, and is obvious evidence of Mike Patton's (Faith No More, Mr. Bungle) influence on his vocal experimentation. The main guitar riff in the song is crunching and groovy, backed by some awesome Brazilian sounding bass and strings. The chorus is a beautiful display of Daniel's higher and mellower vocal abilities. Altogether one of the highlights on the whole album.<br /><br />\\"Spitfall\\" is very wordy and is another song largely using 'rapping' throughout - the chorus kind of generic - possibly the worst song on the album but still good and very interesting nonetheless. 'Yo'.<br /><br />\\"Cribcaged\\" is a mellower tune with very catchy melodies accompanied by some explicit words of aggression which may be a little overdone. Beautiful piano and acoustic guitar work along with higher background vocal harmonies.<br /><br />\\"America\\" has stirred up some controversy because of the content of the lyrics. Daniel explains some of it in the morow website interview - basically the aggression is towards the American government, and his personal critique does come through in the concept, however he does ask the American people \\"If I say I love you, dare you love me too?\\". The satyrical content of the song can and has been expressed by many other AMERICAN bands! Musically the song is not that appealing to me, but does fit the concept quite well - very funky and different, mixing in different elements of American pop-culture to create the desired mood of the song.<br /><br />DISCLAIMER: Lyrically remember that THIS IS A CONCEPT ALBUM, therefore does have a story it is trying to tell. The same statement that Daniel made in the insert of TPEI would also apply to Scarsick:<br /><br />\\"Even though parts of this concept and its emotions are influenced by our lives and others' we want to emphasise that it should not be seen as an autobiography or true story. However, we hope and believe that anybody with the ability to feel pity and empathy should be able to relate to this story and recognise themselves throughout the album. If not in the situations then at least in the spectra of emotions displayed through them.\\"<br /><br />\\"Disco Queen\\" has elements similar to the band Killers album 'Hot Fuss'. The song as a whole hasmore of an experimental than an actual 'disco' sound. I would compare it more to the efforts of Mr Bungle's self titled album. 'Disco Queen' is not the most complex song that POS has composed, but is definitely the most different from anything they have done before - that said, it is actually a very enjoyable song.<br /><br />\\"Kingdom of Loss\\" is a beautiful arrangement on the mellower side for the most part, yet filled with the angst of the character being displayed through Daniel's vocals during heavier moments. Conceptually the song shows the character reflecting on the world around him and seeing the depressed state of things whereas 'King of Loss' from TPEI saw the character's disappointment in his life and what was expected of him. It seems that his search for independence and a meaningful existence only leaves him disenchanted with society as a whole.<br /><br />\\"Mrs. Modern Mother Mary\\" is a sarcastic look at religion with distorted bending guitar riffs similar to Alice In Chain's sound, particularly the song 'Man in the Box'. Quite a dark but groovy song with a catchy chorus.<br /><br />\\"Idiocracy\\" probably sounds more similar to previous albums than any other song on 'Scarsick', a very atmospheric song employing many different instruments and sound techniques. Lyrically another song projecting frustration towards external institutions of society - see 'Idioglossia' from TPEI. Any older fan of POS should love this epic song.<br /><br />\\"Flame to the Moth\\" is the heaviest song on the album that sees Daniel using vocal methods he has not previously ventured out into before. The screaming he does (only in small portions of the song) is similar to the vocalist from the band Blindside. AWESOME SONG!!!<br /><br />\\"Enter Rain\\" is the 10 minute+ epic of the album. A Pink Floyd-like ambient sound with a POS twist and probably the most emotionally moving song on 'Scarsick' - the perfect song to finish the album.<br /><br />In conclusion, this album is great - perhaps not a masterpiece like previous efforts, but a 5 star album for sure. Don't expect it to sound anything like TPEI - just expect beautiful musicianship!!!<br /><br />RECOMMENDATION: If you are just reading reviews to check out POS then you may want to begin your collection with 'One Hour By the Concrete Lake' instead of 'Scarsick'. If you are a fan of progressive rock that really does 'progress' then this album should suit your tastes. If you do like the diversity and experimentation on 'Scarsick' then you should definitely purchase Faith No More's 1992 album 'Angel Dust'. Ok - I am done. ;)as a whole has more of an experimental than an actual 'disco' sound. I would compare it more to the efforts of Mr Bungle's self titled album. 'Disco Queen' is not the most complex song that POS has composed, but is definitely the most different from anything they have done before - that said, it is actually a very enjoyable song. <br /> <br />\\"Kingdom of Loss\\" is a beautiful arrangement on the mellower side for the most part, yet filled with the angst of the character being displayed through Daniel's vocals during heavier moments. Conceptually the song shows the character reflecting on the world around him and seeing the depressed state of things whereas 'King of Loss' from TPEI saw the character's disappointment in his life and what was expected of him. It seems that his search for independence and a meaningful existence only leaves him disenchanted with society as a whole.  <br /> <br />\\"Mrs. Modern Mother Mary\\" is a sarcastic look at religion with distorted bending guitar riffs similar to Alice In Chain's sound, particularly the song 'Man in the Box'. Quite a dark but groovy song with a catchy chorus. <br /> <br />\\"Idiocracy\\" probably sounds more similar to previous albums than any other song on 'Scarsick', a very atmospheric song employing many different instruments and sound techniques. Lyrically another song projecting frustration towards external institutions of society - see 'Idioglossia' from TPEI. Any older fan of POS should love this epic song. <br /> <br />\\"Flame to the Moth\\" is the heaviest song on the album that sees Daniel using vocal methods he has not previously ventured out into before. The screaming he does (only in small portions of the song) is similar to the vocalist from the band Blindside. AWESOME SONG!!! <br /> <br />\\"Enter Rain\\" is the 10 minute+ epic of the album. A Pink Floyd-like ambient sound with a POS twist and probably the most emotionally moving song on 'Scarsick' - the perfect song to finish the album. <br /> <br />In conclusion,this album is great - perhaps not a masterpiece like previous efforts, but a 5 star album for sure. Don't expect it to sound anything like TPEI - just expect beautiful musicianship!!! <br /> <br />RECOMMENDATION: If you are just reading reviews to check out POS then you may want to begin your collection with 'One Hour By the Concrete Lake' instead of 'Scarsick'. If you are a fan of progressive rock that really does 'progress' then this album should suit your tastes. B00003CXP1|5.0|This is one of those movies that you almost get annoyed hearing about now cause it's so \\"cool,\\" but it deserves the acclaim it receives. For anyone interested in film, history or technique, this movie is required material. following up on PI, Aronofsky utilizes extremely heavy stylization that identifies his whole oeuvre. I won't bother with a synopsis, since you can find that elsewhere and that's not what the film is about anyway. In addition to actually pioneering new techniques in his films, including a camera actually mounted on the actor for reverse-POV shots, which i have subsequently seen used in other films. Few filmmakers can so poignantly convey the experience of a migraine headache as Mr. Aronofsky and watching the movie can be a draining experience, which is a testament to the director's skill since that was obviously his intention. B000LPQ6DE|5.0|The photography, costumes and dialogue are very well done in this most recent adaptation of Bronte's classic. Upon first viewing Mr. Rochester, I did not think he was good looking. His hair was askew, his demeanor demonstrative and authoratative...frankly I found him to be what he was supposed to be: harsh, angry and rude. When first seeing the quiet Miss Eyre, he is not beguiled or friendly, but instead shows his true colors as the tormented soul that he is. As with any good relationship worth waiting for; one with substance, the viewer slowly sees inside the bravado, sinical attitude and agitated angst that torments Mr. Rochester. The director allows us to see a more thorough interpretation of the characters that have enthralled many for so long.    In reference to the passion, one knows that a simple touch of the hand was seen as an intimate gesture during this time period. But in allowing us to view both Rochester's and Eyre's dance with each other, we have a more intimate portrayal of two people who have suffered and as all people that are drawn to each other, subject each other to games and eventually their inner most selves. One knows that a woman was viewed as secondary even with family wealth during the era that this story takes place. Therefore having to know one's place, yet with strength, move forward as a woman and handle the challenges that befall her, actress Ruth Wilson does a superb job of interpreting the epitomy of grace and sanity which has eluded Mr. Rochester in his search to be loved and to love.    Actor Toby Stevens only flaw would be that with his theatre background, he sometimes comes off as though he were playing to a packed house of thousands as some thespians who have a great deal of theatre training and background do. However, these are momentary moments of exaggeration that do not affect the story and somewhat enhance the flawed Mr. Rochester as he is the master of his domain, although it is a living hell to him, and he is the epitomeof a a character in a patriarchal society in which man is king.    To see the twists and turns and the more in depth emotions of these two characters brought to life, with the vivid imagery, excellent dialogue and the ability of these two characters to be so intwined as to truly know how to handle each other was a pleasure to watch. I applaud PBS and only ask for more.
B000J10ER4|5.0|I was really excited when I found out they were going to be showing parts of this movie in 3-D at Imax.  Unfortunately I wasn't able to get to the theatre in time (my local Imax is two hours away).     I thought I was just going to have to suffer and watch it in regular 2-D until I found out there is a new type of 3-D glasses that work on regular movies. I was amazed![[ASIN:B000W9Y294 TV Eyes 3-D Glasses: Watch any movie in 3-D]] It didn't look like the old red/green 3-D, for one it didn't mess up the colors, but it did make the picture look clearer and deeper and the people looked more solid. It didn't jump out of the screen at me like it would have at Imax, but then I don't have a thirty foot television either.     What was really great about Superman Returns was that parts of the movie had been deliberately made for 3-D, so the effect looked especially good on those parts.  But I also got to watch the rest of the movie in 3-D too, which I wouldn't have got to do at Imax.    The scene where Superman is catching the airplane looked great. In fact, all the flying scenes looked better. I've watched the movie in regular 2-D (it's just a regular dvd after all) and somehow when you watch it in 3-D it looks more like he's really up there in the sky, it seems like he has more weight and could really fall.  When you see it in 2-D he's just sort of stuck in the picture, like he's pasted onto the sky.    Considering they had a new actor playing Superman I thought he did a really wonderful job. Not only was he trying to portray and upbeat, modern version of Superman, but he was also trying to be Christopher Reeves at the same time. He did a superb job.  I always hated in the old movies how they had Clark Kent being a dork, and Lex Luthor wasn't much better, but in this new version they're more believable.  Still a bit over the top at times, but then they are based on comic book characters.  And at least Luthor is bald.  Actually the actor they got to play him was perfect forthe part, he even looked like the Luthor I remember from the old 80's comics, a bit stocky and bald as an egg, but carrying it off   with power and style.    I really loved all the sly references to the movie they put in there. I didn't even notice a lot of them the first time because they were done so smooth, they didn't feel out of context at all.    And you can really tell that the director was a comic book fan, there are several scenes in the movie taken directly from the comics. The scene where Superman stops the womans car, and has to put it down gently, front end first, is right off the cover of the very first Superman Action comic book.  And the scene where Superman is flying down into his Fortress of Solitude, one leg sort of drawn up, and most of him in shadow, is almost exactly a rendition of one of the more modern Superman iconic posters.     They did a far better job on this movie than I expected.  There's more human warmth and struggle to it than you'd expect from a superhero movie. I hope they go on to make more.
